titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Keller Lectures collection ARCH075
titlestmt.author: Ethel Bacon; Margaret Mair, 2010; Sean Parke, Nov. 2017.
titlestmt.sponsor: The digitization of the recordings in the Keller Lectures Collection was funded by Robert and Anthony Keller, with additional support from The Women's Advancement Initiative's Dorothy Goodwin Scholars Program, which was made possible thanks to a generous bequest from Dorothy Goodwin. The Women's Advancement Initiative at the University of Hartford is proud to continue the legacy of advancing each woman's potential in the Hartford College for Women tradition.

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Hartford Archives & Special Collections

note.p: Ethel Bacon created the original finding aid; updated and revised by Margaret Mair, 2010; transcribed to ArchivesSpace from word document finding aid by Sean Parke in Dec. 2015; updated and revised by Sean Parke Nov. 2017.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-25 14:15:48 -0500.

change.item: rehoused, rearranged, added 2 accessions from 2016, and revised
Updated finding aid following digitization of the Keller recordings (acc. 2018-09-17-01). Added digital objects and linked them to each recording.
Added two phonograph records of 1958 Wyzanski lecture found with Hartt phonograph records (ARCH138). Recording in four parts on two discs.

repository.corpname: University of Hartford Archives & Special Collections

did.unittitle: Keller Lectures collection
did.abstract: The collection contains materials pertaining to the Keller Lectures from 1958-1976, including planning and publicity materials, photographs, transcripts, and recordings.

dao.xlink:title: Digitized Keller Lectures collection

daodesc.p: Digitized Keller Lectures collection

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection may be protected by copyright law (U.S. Code: Title 17). Any use of the material which exceeds fair use requires permission from the copyright holder. Researchers are solely responsible for obtaining the proper permission(s) for their use of the material.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: A portion of the collection has been digitized, including all of the recordings in the collection. Digitized materials can be accessed at: http://mdid3.hartford.edu/explore/explore/?c=allcollections:88. Public access to the digital repository is limited to the University of Hartford Campus. Students, faculty, and staff can login anywhere with their university email and password.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note - Alexander S. Keller
bioghist.p: Alexander Sidney Keller was born in New York City on August 5, 1905 to Elsie Davidson Keller and Sidney A. Keller. He went to Far Rockaway High School in Long Island and later graduated from Harvard College in 1926 and the Harvard School of Business Administration in 1928. He married Carolyn Witmark in 1932. Keller settled in Hartford in 1932 to head the Pratt & Whitney Company's Keller Division, formerly the Keller Mechanical Engineering Co. of Brooklyn, founded by his father. Keller went on to become Pratt & Whitney's Vice President and General Sales Manager.

During World War II, he served on Advisory Committees for the War Production Board, the National Production Authority, and the Department of Commerce. He served as Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of the National Machine Tool Builders Association and also on its Committee on governmental relations.

After the war, Mr. Keller and his family spent two years in Holland where, as Senior Industry Officer of the Marshall Plan Mission, he oversaw the effective allocation of three hundred million aid dollars. He was decorated by the Queen of the Netherlands for his outstanding work in reestablishing war-torn Holland on a sound economic and productive basis.

Throughout his life, Mr. Keller exhibited a sincere and profound interest in the dignity and rights of the individual. At no time was this quality so rewarding to society as when the need for refugee service was born. Founder of the Refugee Service of Hartford in 1938, he subsequently became Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Refugee Service and as such was responsible for resettling hundreds of refugees who had escaped from Nazi Germany and from behind the Iron Curtain. He gave unstintingly of his time and effort to their problems on resettlement, housing, jobs, language barriers, emotional readjustment, and citizenship.

Mr. Keller also participated in a leadership capacity in many community activities involving social services including the Hartford Jewish Federation, Hartford Jewish Community Council, USO, Community Chest, YMCA, Girl Scouts, Symphony Society, Wadsworth Atheneum, and the American Jewish Committee. He was also a founder of the University of Hartford.

Above all came his devotion to his family and friends. It was his friends who were inspired to start this memorial to Mr. Keller. As one has expressed it so ably, "Al was a warm person who liked his fellowmen. No matter how busy his schedule he always had time to listen to someone else's problem and to extend a helping hand. His name was synonymous with good works in community endeavors."

Mr. Keller passed away on the afternoon of May 16, 1958. The Alexander S. Keller Memorial Fund, was established later that year by his family and friends, to enable the University to expose students and the interested public to the live and lively ideas and ideals of the great philosophers, writers, artists, and statesmen of their time.

[Alexander Keller biographical note is a revised version of a short biography which appeared in the 1964-1965 Keller Lecture program. This bio also includes information obtained from: "Alexander Keller Dies; P & W Co. Vice President," The Hartford Courant, May 17, 1958, http://libill.hartford.edu:2048/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/553225574?accountid=11308 (accessed November 22, 2017); as well as additional information from the Keller Family]

bioghist.head: Biographical Note - Carolyn W. Keller
bioghist.p: Carolyn Keller was born in 1910 in Woodmere, Long Island to Viola Cahn Witmark and Isidore Witmark. Mrs. Keller attended Woodmere Academy and Wellesley College. She was a significant community leader in the Hartford area and held several leadership roles throughout her life, including chairwomen of the Citizens Committee for the Connecticut Medical-Dental School, chair of the Greater Hartford Chapter of the American Jewish Committee, secretary of the Governor's Site Selection Commission which chose the location of the UConn Health Center, and secretary of the West Hartford Charter Revision Commission, to name a few. Mrs. Keller was also a regent of the University of Hartford. When her husband died in 1958, she helped establish the Alexander S. Keller Memorial Lecture Series at the University and curated and managed the series for the next decade. In 1968, Mrs. Keller received an honorary doctorate of humane letters from the University. She passed away on July 30, 1968.

[Much of the information from this note was obtained from "Mrs. A. S. Keller Dies at 58; was UofH Regent." The Hartford Courant (1923-1991), Jul 31, 1968, http://libill.hartford.edu:2048/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/549848559?accountid=11308 (accessed November 27, 2017); as well as from the Keller Family.]

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2015, the call number was changed from K65K to ARCH075.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains letters, memos, programs, press releases, newspaper clippings, transcripts, and recordings of Keller lecture events. The collection also contains records of the University of Hartford Committee on Keller Lectures, which includes meeting minutes, financial records, and other materials including records of two events honoring Carolyn Keller.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into five series: I. Lecture Seasons, II. University of Hartford Committee on Keller Lectures, III. Photographs, IV. Recordings, V. Duplicates.

did.unittitle: Lecture Seasons

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publicity materials, planning documents, programs, and transcripts of the Keller Lectures from 1958-2007 (although the lectures ended in 1976, this series includes publicity that the lectures received years later). Recordings of the lectures can be found in Series IV: Recordings. Additional information regarding the planning of the lectures by the lecture committee can be found in Series II: University of Hartford Committee on Keller Lectures, 1958-1975.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in order by lecture season.

did.unittitle: Season 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials including programs, advertisements, press releases, and transcripts (not all lectures have all of the aforementioned materials) for the three lectures of the inaugural season: "The Living Hand: The Role of Tradition in a Democratic Society," by Dr. Charles E. Wyzanski, Jr. (Nov. 10, 1958); "Foreign Policy and Social Change," by John Kenneth Galbraith (Jan. 12, 1959); and "The Future of Integration," by Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. (May 7, 1959).

did.unittitle: Season 2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials including programs, advertisements, press releases, and transcripts (not all lectures have all of the aforementioned materials) for the three lectures of the second season: "The Climate of the Cold War," by William C. Foster (Oct. 20, 1959); "Poetry as Love," by Dr. Mark Van Doren (Dec. 2, 1959); and "The Inevitability of Freedom," by Barbara Ward (Mar. 3, 1960).

did.unittitle: Season 3: Twentieth-Century France: The New Enlightenment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the three Keller lectures, as well as the larger University convocation events of which these lectures were a part. Included are two scrapbooks which belonged to the Keller family, pertaining to the lectures and convocation. The three Keller lectures for this season were: "Albert Camus," by Germaine Bree (Nov. 28, 1960); "DeGaulle and the Fifth Republic," by Raymond Aron (Nov. 29, 1960); and "An Aspect of France and the Visual Arts," by James Johnson Sweeney (Dec. 1, 1960).

did.unittitle: Season 4: The Responsibility of Power

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the three Keller lectures of the fourth season, entitled "The Responsibility of Power." The three lectures for this season were: "Alternatives to Nuclear War," by H. Stuart Hughes (Nov. 16, 1961); "Either-or Thinking," by Herman Kahn (Nov. 30, 1961); and "The Potential for Peace," by Abba Eban (Jan. 25, 1962).

did.unittitle: Season 5

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the Keller lectures of the fifth season which included: "A Reading and Discussion of His Poetry," by Archibald MacLeish (Oct. 23, 1962); "Of Stars and Men," by Harlow Shapley (Nov. 12, 1962); "Romanticism, Politics, and Ethics," by Sir Isaiah Berlin (Jan. 14, 1963).

did.unittitle: Season 6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the Keller lectures and performances of the sixth season including: performances by Donald McKayle and Dance Company (Nov. 25, 1963); "The Redemption of the Robot," by Sir Herbert Read (Mar. 5, 1964); and "Turner and the Liberation of Color," by Sir Kenneth Clark (Apr. 27, 1964); as well as a planned lecture by Aldous Huxley for Oct. 7, 1963 which was cancelled due to Huxley's poor health.

did.unittitle: Season 7: The Shifting Western Alliance

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the four Keller lectures of the seventh season; entitled "The Shifting Western Alliance" [The title of the convocation lectures also appears as "Shifting Western Alliances"]. These lectures include: "NATO and the Shifting Western Alliance," by Dirk U. Stikker (Jan. 4, 1965); "Alliance Strategy and the Political Issues," by Henry A. Kissinger (Jan. 5, 1965); "East-West Relations in Western Diplomacy," by Zbigniew K. Brzezinski (Jan. 6, 1965); and "The United States, France, and the Future of Europe," by Stanley H. Hoffmann (Jan. 7, 1965).

did.unittitle: Season 8: Hidden Languages of the Twentieth Century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the eighth season of the Keller lectures, entitled "Hidden Languages of the Twentieth Century." These lectures included: "Language is More than Words," by Henry Lee Smith, Jr. (Dec. 2, 1965); "GAMES: Theoretical Experiments in Conflict and Cooperation," by Anatol Rapoport (Dec. 7, 1965); "Public Opinion and the Relations Between Nations," by Ithiel De Sola Pool (Dec. 13, 1965).

did.unittitle: Season 9: China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file pertains to the ninth season of the Keller lectures, which was a large convocation on China comprised of several lectures, discussions, roundtables, films, and even a dance performance. Speakers included Harold Jacobson, Edwin O. Reischauer, Harold Isaacs, Donald Zagoria, Arthur Wright, C.T. Hu, Jonathan Spence, Roger Clapp, Frederick Nossal, Gordon Berger, Paul Cohen, Edgar Snow, James Thomson, Giri Deshingkar, Frank Armbruster, Myron Cohen, Carl Riskin, Roy Hofheinz, and Mark Selden, and performers included Averil Tong.

did.unittitle: Season 10: New Horizons for America's Cities

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: File contains materials pertaining to the tenth season of the Keller Lectures, entitled "New Horizons for America's Cities." The lectures for this season included: "Racial Crisis in Perspective," by Gunnar Myrdal (Mar. 12. 1968); "Race and Reality," by Alvin F. Poussaint (Mar. 18, 1968); and "Community Versus City: The New Era in Urban Problems," by James Quinn Wilson (Mar. 25, 1968).

did.unittitle: Season 11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains materials pertaining to the eleventh season of the Keller Lectures, which included, "A Sense of the Past," by Robert Penn Warren (Feb. 11, 1969) and "Technology and Imagination," by Donald Hall (Mar. 5, 1969).

did.unittitle: Season 12: Black Americans Speak through the Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains publicity and planning materials regarding the twelfth season of the Keller lectures, entitled "Black Americans Speak through the Arts," which was a two-and-a-half week program consisting of speakers, performers, and exhibits. The primary participants were the Eleo Pomare Dance Company, Sonia Sanchez, Etheridge Knight, Cliff Frazier, Theodore Gunn, and Jackie McLean.

did.unittitle: Season 13: New Perspectives on Criminal Justice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains the publicity and planning materials of the thirteenth season of the Keller Lectures, entitled "New Perspectives on Criminal Justice." The lectures included, "Crime and the International Context," by Sir Leon Radzinowicz (Mar. 16, 1971); "Crime, Fear and Law Enforcement," by Abraham S. Goldstein (Mar. 18, 1971); and "Legal Protection Against Crime Control Systems," by Alan F. Westin (Mar. 25, 1971).

did.unittitle: Season 14: Film: Today and Tomorrow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains the publicity and planning materials for the fourteenth season of the Keller Lectures, entitled "Film: Today and Tomorrow." The lectures included, "The Film Maker Discusses Some Recent Works," by Standish Lawder (Mar. 13, 1972); "The Cinema as Environment," by Gene Youngblood (Mar. 15, 1972); "The West Coast Independent Film and the Growth of Man," by Sheldon Renan (Mar. 20, 1972); and "Autobiography in the New American Cinema," by Gerald O'Grady (Mar. 22, 1972).

did.unittitle: Season 15: The Nixon-Kissinger Foreign Policy at Home and Abroad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains the publicity and planning materials for the fifteenth season of the Keller Lectures, entitled "The Nixon-Kissinger Foreign Policy at Home and Abroad." The lectures included: "The New Foreign Policy of the United States," by Hans J. Morgenthau (Oct. 31, 1973) and "The United States and Western Europe," by Stanley H. Hoffmann (Apr. 18, 1974 - originally had been scheduled for Oct. 18, 1973). The file also includes an unidentified wound-up red ribbon (located in cassette box).

did.unittitle: Season 16: The United States on the Eve of the Bicentennial

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The file contains the publicity and planning materials pertaining to the sixteenth season of the Keller Lectures, entitled "The United States on the Eve of the Bicentennial." The season had only one lecturer, Alvin F. Poussaint, who had previously been a Keller lecturer in 1968. Poussaint's two-part lecture focused on oppression and repression in America and the effects of the recession on minority citizens.

did.unittitle: Season 17

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The file contains the publicity and planning materials pertaining to the seventeenth and final season of the Keller Lectures. The season's only lecturer was Joseph Alsop, who presented his lecture "Art Collecting as a Social Habit" (Oct. 27, 1976).

did.unittitle: University of Hartford Committee on Keller Lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of the meeting minutes and financial records of the University Committee on Keller Lectures. Also, included are copies of testimonials given at a 1966 luncheon to honor Carolyn Keller for her contributions to the University and the Keller Lectures, as well as papers regarding the memorial service and estate of Carolyn Keller following her passing in 1968.

did.unittitle: Financial Records
University Committee on Keller Lectures Meeting Minutes
Testimonial Luncheon honoring Mrs. Carolyn Keller
Carolyn Keller Memorial Service and Keller Estate
Publicity
Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of photographs of the Keller Lecture events and headshots provided by the speakers to the University for promotional purposes. The series also contains photographs from a memorial for Carolyn Keller on October 22, 1968.

did.unittitle: Recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the recordings of the Keller Lecture events. Transcripts for some of these recordings can be found in Series I: Lecture Seasons.

did.unittitle: The Living Hand: The Role of Tradition in a Democratic Society; Dr. Charles E. Wyzanski, Jr.

physdesc.physfacet: Likely duplicate of audio reel recording, in four parts on two discs. Lacquer disc.

dao.xlink:title: The Living Hand: The Role of Tradition in a Democratic Society

daodesc.p: The Living Hand: The Role of Tradition in a Democratic Society: 1958 Nov 10

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This audio recording is of the first Keller Lecture. The lecture was presented by Dr. Charles E. Wyzanski, Jr. entitled "The Living Hand: The Role of Tradition in a Democratic Society." The recording includes introductions by Alan Wilson and remarks by Edward Allen.

did.unittitle: Modern Art in a Modern World; Sir Kenneth Clark

dao.xlink:title: Modern Art in a Modern World

daodesc.p: Modern Art in a Modern World: 1964 Apr 28

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The recording is of Sir Kenneth Clark the morning after his lecture on Turner and his use of color. The talk was a more informal discussion based on student questions on art. Despite being marketed by the University as a talk on modern art, Clark states that he is not an expert in modern art and is an art historian.

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of a faculty symposium held at the beginning of the Keller Lecture's eighth season. Participants included George M. Evica, Malthon Anapol, William Brayfield, and John Margerones.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Two versions of the recording exist. One version is split across three reels (arch075av0061-arch075av0063) and another is on two sides of one reel (arch075av0146). Both versions were digitized. While the version from three reels may sound better in spots, it is missing 17 seconds from Carolyn Keller's speech on the third reel. Therefore, the one-reel version is the one that is publically available. To access the other version, contact archives@hartford.edu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: According to press releases in the collection, this event was a preview of the forthcoming Keller lectures on China that occured on Dec. 12-15. This event was to include talks from University of Hartford Professors: Albert F. Hamel, Eugene T. Sweeney, and Ivan Galantic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The recording is of the roundtable discussion entitled, "The Nature of Chinese Power in Asia," which featured Harrison E. Salisbury, as the moderator, and Harold Jacobson [who replaced Robert W. Barnett], Edwin Reischauer, Harold Isaacs, and Donald Zagoria as the participants. The discussion was broadcast on WHNB-TV, Channel 30, live from WHNB-TV studios.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This recording was rebroadcast by WTIC on April 1, 1971 (which is why the reels are marked with this date, rather than the date the lecture was recorded.).

did.unittitle: Panel Discussion

dao.xlink:title: Panel Discussion

daodesc.p: Panel Discussion: 1971 Mar 26

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The March 26, 1971 panel discussed Alan Westin's lecture. Panelists included Alan Westin, State Senator Jay W. Jackson, Captain Wayne H. Bishop of the State Police, and Attorney Alvin Pudlin who was a cooperating attorney with the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union.

did.unittitle: Duplicates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of duplicate documents and photographs found throughout the collection. The majority of the duplicates are programs and transcripts from Series I: Lecture Seasons.
